title: Introduction to Carban
content:
1. Carban is an organic chemical entity that contains a carbon atom with three bonds.  
2. It is a radical, meaning it has unpaired electrons.  
3. Carban can participate in various chemical reactions due to its reactive nature.

title: Types of Carban
content:
1. Positive Carban: Also known as carbocations, they have a positive charge.  
2. Negative Carban: Known as carbanions, these have a negative charge.  
3. Neutral Carban: Represents a carban that is neutral and has three covalent bonds.

title: Formation of Carban
content:
1. Carban can be formed through various reactions like polymerization or photolytic cleavage.  
2. It plays a pivotal role in organic reactions, especially in radical mechanisms.  
3. Stability of carban determined by substituents around the carbon.

title: Reactions Involving Carban
content:
1. Carban reacts with electrophiles to form new compounds.  
2. It can also abstract hydrogen from other molecules.  
3. It participates in addition reactions due to its high reactivity.

title: Compounds Containing Carban
content:
1. Carbenes: Compounds where a carban is bonded to two other atoms.  
2. Azo Compounds: Contain nitrogen to stabilize carban and related radicals.  
3. Current uses in pharmaceuticals and material sciences.

title: Importance of Carban Compounds
content:
1. Play a significant role in organic synthesis.  
2. Utilized in the manufacture of plastics and rubber.  
3. Important in biochemical processes and reactions.

title: Carban in Laboratory Synthesis
content:
1. Carban compounds are synthesized in laboratories for research.  
2. Used to create complex organic molecules.  
3. Critical in developing new materials and pharmaceuticals.

title: Challenges in Handling Carban Compounds
content:
1. Highly reactive nature makes them difficult to handle.  
2. Stability issues can lead to hazardous situations in experiments.  
3. Need for proper safety measures and protocols in laboratories.
